scene.name: intro
scene.line: You are in Bedquilt, a long east/west passage with holes everywhere.
*JOSEPH* and *LULA* remove the computer equipment they are carrying on their backs, and begin setting up.
That's the last trip. So everything's down here now ...

scene.name: bedquilt-talk-to-lula
scene.line: `(Typing.)` ~Say something back.~
You make an awkward joke.
Don't be so morbid.

scene.name: bedquilt-set-up-gear
scene.line: `(Typing.)` ~Set up gear.~
I only understood you as far as wanting to set the up above.
"Set the up above" ... ?

scene.name: bedquilt-lula-pensive
scene.line: LULA looks pensive.

scene.name: bedquilt-lula-dialog-choices
scene.option: Ask her where the treasure is.

scene.name: bedquilt-ask-lula-about-gear
scene.line: `(Typing.)` ~Ask Lula about gear.~
Sure, Donald. We may as well take inventory.
I've got the tape machine and the synthesizer parts we "borrowed" from the School of Music. It's all tuned up to my voice so we won't have to type so much.
Joseph has his slate, and the punched cards he's transcribed from the poems we read him. He's got the typewriter and the paper tape reader.
And you've got the CRT display. How's your back holding up?

scene.name: bedquilt-ask-lula-about-cave
scene.line: `(Typing.)` ~Ask Lula about cave.~
Having second thoughts? I don't blame you; it's ... unsettling down here. Weird acoustics.
Earlier, as we were climbing down, I thought I heard voices for a moment. Or ... not voices themselves, but the echoes of voices, singing. Some kind of eerie, tuneless working song.
I'm glad I'm not down here alone.

scene.name: bedquilt-ask-lula-about-treasure
scene.line: `(Typing.)` ~Ask Lula where the treasure is.~
Ha. If we knew that, we wouldn't have to set up down here ...
I know you think this environment will help our project, get us in touch with a deep romantic reverence for some kind of profound natural spookiness ... but I was more comfortable in our lab.
The university picked the worst time to cut our funding! Typical institutional stinginess and academic politics. I mean, I felt like we were getting really close to something ... something ...
Anyway, I don't know if it's sustainable down here. You know, to live and work here ... together.

scene.name: bedquilt-construction
scene.line: *JOSEPH* looks uncomfortable.
Jealous ...
Hey, Donald, can you help me, uh ... wire up these generators?
I'll assemble the synthesizer. But I could use some help with the serial interface, if you have time.
You hear an unfamiliar echo from a tunnel to the east.
scene.option: Maybe if we help Lula, she'll have some more to tell us.

scene.name: construction-help-joseph
scene.line: `(Typing.)` ~Help Joseph.~
I appreciate it, Donald. I'm not much of an electrician, you know ... you know that.
*JOSEPH* hands you a bundle of wires. His kitten curls up on a spool of cabling.
Listen. The three of us had a good thing for a minute, wouldn't you say? Up at the old place? Before it got ugly?

I'm saying ... We came down here to work. To really do it. XANADU. And I mean we've got to be rational about this. All three of us have got to put our feelings aside for a bit and be rational ... do you know what I'm saying?
scene.option: Is he talking about Lula? Kind of creepy.
Just agree with whatever he's saying; this isn't helpful.

scene.name: joseph-back-off
scene.line: `(Typing.)` ~Tell Joseph to back off.~
*JOSEPH* wipes his brow with a dusty sleeve.
Seems ... down here, we're all strangers. Permanently strange.

scene.name: joseph-ok
scene.line: `(Typing.)` ~Agree with Joseph.~
*JOSEPH* sets down the wire-strippers in his hand.
You really mean that?
You're pretty OK, Donald. I mean you have a clear idea on what's sensible. We're in unmapped territory here, strange to the whole thing. Got to have a focus. She'll understand.

scene.name: construction-help-lula
scene.line: `(Typing.)` ~Help Lula.~
Thanks, Donald. I can never remember which color lead goes to which pin ...
*LULA* begins unpacking a box of wires and terminals.
Do you think there are paintings down here? Cave paintings, I mean. Maybe some old pottery shards, from when the world was young and early men and women huddled in these caves to ...
Do you know, I think cultural fossils are the saddest fossils? Sadder than animal remains, I mean ...

We might come across a petrified mollusk, or a partial dinosaur footprint, and we say: "there was a point of contact here, where a body touched the earth, and maybe there's a little bit of evidential garbage, but the life who owned that body never cared and has moved on anyway."
And that's the end of it.
But suppose I shine my lantern on one of these walls, and I see a crude painting, thousands of years old. Two men and a woman. Charcoal and blood, on rock.
Someone put that there, to keep something on the rock after she passed. A hope, a relationship, or a moment. A worry, maybe ... a regret.

She made a painting to keep something alive for her, but like that dead mollusk and that itinerant dinosaur, she had to move on. Whatever it was is gone, and now we're looking at this painting. This dangling copy, with no original.

scene.name: to-tunnels-after-conversation
scene.line: You are interrupted by the ominous echo of a grating, scraping sound from the east, louder than before.
What the hell was that?
Let's check it out.
